revision.text:
{{Use British English|date=August 2011}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2011}} {{Infobox person |name = Isabel Fay |honorific_suffix = |image = Comedy actress & writer Isabel Fay.jpg |caption = Comedy actress & writer Isabel Fay |birth_name = |birth_date = |birth_place = [[Bath, Somerset]], UK |alma_mater = [[Royal Holloway University of London]] |occupation = Actress, comedian, writer |years_active = |spouse = |children = |website = {{URL|www.isabelfay.com/}}
{{URL|www.cleverpie.com/}} }} '''Isabel Fay''' is a British comedy writer and performer. ==Early life and education== Fay was born in [[Bath, Somerset|Bath]] in 1979 and graduated from [[Royal Holloway University of London]] in 2001 with a [[2:1]] [[BA (Hons)]]. ==Career== ===TV, film and radio=== Fay appeared in the first series of [[BBC2]]'s ''[[How Not to Live Your Life]]''[https://www.imdb.com/name/nm2543576/ Isabel Fay's IMDB listings] with [[Dan Clark]] and [[David Armand]] and co-starred with Dan Clark in ''Dan Clark's Guide to Dating'' for [[Comedy Central]].{{cite web |url=http://www.comedycentral.co.uk/shows/dan-clarks-guide-to-dating |title=Dan Clark's Guide To Dating |publisher=[[Comedy Central (UK and Ireland)]] |date= |accessdate=8 June 2012}} In 2011 Fay's self-penned debut short film ''With or Without U2'' won Best Comedy Short at the [[L.A. Comedy Shorts Film Festival]], despite the controversy surrounding the film's soundtrack. Fay wrote it to a choral score of [[U2]]'s [[With or Without You]], but the band personally declined her the license to use the score. Fay arranged for a chorus to sing the score live along to the muted film. Fay appeared in the film ''Clive Hole'', adapted from a short story by [[Alexi Sayle]] and starring [[David Schneider (actor)|David Schneider]], [[Karl Theobald]] and Susan Vidler. She also appeared in the film ''Rekindle'' by Marios Hamboulides, starring [[Tom Conti]], [[Karl Theobald]] and ''[[My Family]]''{{'}}s [[Daniela Denby-Ashe]], and she voiced the short film ''Man in a Cat'' with [[Kevin Eldon]] and [[Josie Long]]. For [[CBBC]] Fay appeared in children's comedy shows ''Little Howard's Big Question'' and ''Hacker Time''. She was a member of the cast for [[E4 (channel)|E4]]'s ''[[Dogface (TV series)|Dogface]]'', and appeared in the [[BBC]]'s ''Comedy Shuffle'' and ''[[The Royal Bodyguard]]''. She also wrote and performed in all three series of [[ITV2]]'s flagship show ''[[Comedy Cuts]]'' and has shot her own sketch show pilot with Silver River TV. For [[BBC Radio 4]] Fay starred in sitcom pilot ''49 Cedar Street'', and appeared as a supporting comedy character in ''[[Sarah Millican]]'s Support Group''. ===Live comedy shows=== Fay co-created and starred in sketch show ''The Works'' with [[David Armand]] at Madame Jojo's in [[Soho]] Fay's solo live work is usually a collaboration with [[if.comeddies]] award-winning director Matt Holt (who directed [[Brendon Burns (comedian)|Brendan Burns']] [[if.comeddies]] award-winning show 2007) and [[Perrier award]]-winning producer Tom Hopgood (who produced [[Laura Solon]]'s [[Perrier award]] winning show in 2005). Fay has written and performed three solo comedy shows at the [[Edinburgh Festival Fringe]], first appearing with her "Magic Steve's Disappearing Act" (featuring her [[magician's assistant]] character, Annette Cadabra) in 2006.[http://www.chortle.co.uk/shows/edinburgh_fringe_2006/m/14684/magic_steves_disappearing_act/review/ Magic Steve's Disappearing Act' review : Chortle : The UK Comedy Guide]. Chortle. Retrieved on 26 August 2011. She appeared in her second solo show, "Isabel Fay: Altar Ego", in 2007;{{cite news |url=http://www.metro.co.uk/metrolife/edinburgh/comedy/article.html?in_article_id=62766&in_page_id=31 |title=Isabel Fay: Altar Ego |publisher=Metro.co.uk |date=22 August 2007 |accessdate=8 June 2012}} and her third, "Don't Let A Gift Horse in the House", at the [[Pleasance]] Courtyard in 2008.[http://www.metro.co.uk/metrolife/257055-isabel-fay-dont-let-a-gift-horse-in-the-house Isabel Fay: Don't Let A Gift Horse In The House]. Metro.co.uk (10 August 2008). Retrieved on 26 August 2011. ===Internet comedy=== Along with Tom Hopgood, Fay co-owns [[production company]] Clever Pie, which makes online comedy sketches and films.[http://www.cleverpie.com/ Internet comedy production company Clever Pie's website]. Cleverpie.com. Retrieved on 26 August 2011. On 8 June 2012 Clever Pie released a musical sketch entitled "Thank You Hater!", which immediately went [[Viral video|viral]].{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2012/jun/09/thank-you-hater-trolls?newsfeed=true |title=Thank you hater: comedian hits back at trolls in mock tribute |date=9 June 2012 |accessdate=9 June 2012 |publisher=[[The Guardian]]}}{{cite web |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/internet/9320896/Thank-You-Hater-video-by-Isabel-Fay-trumps-trolls-with-tribute-track.html |title='Thank You Hater' video by Isabel Fay trumps trolls with tribute track |date=8 June 2012 |accessdate=9 June 2012 |publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]}}{{cite web |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2012/06/08/thank-you-hater-by-isabel-fay-trolling_n_1580041.html |title='Thank You Hater!' By Isabel Fay Tells All Internet Trolls To Go Jump Off A Bridge |date=8 June 2012 |accessdate=8 June 2012 |publisher=[[Huffington Post]]}} [[Stephen Fry]] described the sketch as "a masterpiece".{{cite web |url=https://twitter.com/stephenfry/status/211070241483145216 |title=How to feed trolls |publisher=Stephen Fry's [[Twitter]] feed |date=8 June 2012 |accessdate=8 June 2012}} For [[BBC]] Comedy Online Fay wrote and performed the short film ''Common Film Ground''[http://www.bbc.co.uk/comedy/clips/p0092htl/randoms_common_film_ground/ Common Film Ground on BBC Comedy] and co-wrote and starred in ''Leader's Wives''.[http://www.bbc.co.uk/comedy/clips/p007h9mh/randoms_leaders_wives/ Leader's Wives on BBC Comedy] She also produced an exclusive sketch for [[Funny Or Die]] set to [[Bonnie Tyler]]'s hit "[[Total Eclipse of the Heart]]" called "Total Paperclips of the Heart".[http://www.funnyordie.co.uk/videos/0c48868303/total-paperclips-of-the-heart-from-fod-team-uk?rel=user&rel_pos=2 Total Paperclips of the Heart on Funny or Die]. Funnyordie.co.uk (22 August 2011). Retrieved on 26 August 2011. Fay wrote and performed as a roving reporter on Monkey TV's online show ''Newslog'', which also stars [[Steve Punt]]. ==External links== *[http://www.isabelfay.com/ Fay's official homepage] *[http://www.cleverpie.com/ Clever Pie's official website] *[https://www.youtube.com/user/cleverpie Clever Pie's YouTube channel] *[https://www.youtube.com/user/isabelfaycomedy Fay's pre-Clever Pie YouTube channel] * {{IMDb name|2543576|Isabel Fay}} == References == {{reflist|30em}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Fay, Isabel}} [[Category:1979 births]] [[Category:Alumni of Royal Holloway, University of London]] [[Category:English television actresses]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Bath, Somerset]] [[Category:English women comedians]]
